Commuter Model With Vax Data

Source: ../vignettes/including_vax.Rmd
including_vax.Rmd

We begin with a blank SEIIAR data.table:

library(data.table)
print(spread::nor_seiiar_noinfected_2017_b2020)
#>        location_code      S E I Ia R
#>   1: municip_nor0301 666759 0 0  0 0
#>   2: municip_nor1101  14899 0 0  0 0
#>   3: municip_nor1103 140856 0 0  0 0
#>   4: municip_nor1106  37166 0 0  0 0
#>   5: municip_nor1108  76742 0 0  0 0
#>  ---                                
#> 352: municip_nor5440    991 0 0  0 0
#> 353: municip_nor5441   2911 0 0  0 0
#> 354: municip_nor5442    951 0 0  0 0
#> 355: municip_nor5443   2267 0 0  0 0
#> 356: municip_nor5444  10199 0 0  0 0

We then take a vax data.table that has the proportion of vaccinated people for each location_code:

vax_measles <- spread::nor_childhood_vax_b2020[
  calyear==2016 & 
  vaccine=="measles"
  ]

print(vax_measles)
#>      calyear   location_code age vaccine vaccination_coverage_pr100
#>   1:    2016    county_nor03 016 measles                   92.41643
#>   2:    2016    county_nor11 016 measles                   92.41643
#>   3:    2016    county_nor15 016 measles                   92.41643
#>   4:    2016    county_nor18 016 measles                   92.41643
#>   5:    2016    county_nor30 016 measles                   92.41643
#>  ---                                                               
#> 364:    2016 municip_nor5441 016 measles                   82.38342
#> 365:    2016 municip_nor5442 016 measles                   92.41643
#> 366:    2016 municip_nor5443 016 measles                   93.38235
#> 367:    2016 municip_nor5444 016 measles                   88.73874
#> 368:    2016      nation_nor 016 measles                   92.41643
#>      vaccination_coverage_pr1 imputed
#>   1:                0.9241643    TRUE
#>   2:                0.9241643    TRUE
#>   3:                0.9241643    TRUE
#>   4:                0.9241643    TRUE
#>   5:                0.9241643    TRUE
#>  ---                                 
#> 364:                0.8238342   FALSE
#> 365:                0.9241643    TRUE
#> 366:                0.9338235   FALSE
#> 367:                0.8873874   FALSE
#> 368:                0.9241643   FALSE

We then use the function convert_blank_seiiar_with_vax to combine the two:

nor_seiiar_measles_noinfected_2017 <- spread::convert_blank_seiiar_with_vax(
  seiiar = spread::nor_seiiar_noinfected_2017_b2020, 
  vax = vax_measles
  )

We now have a data.table that contains “recovered” people (i.e. vaccinated people):

print(nor_seiiar_measles_noinfected_2017)
#>        location_code     S E I Ia      R
#>   1: municip_nor0301 59775 0 0  0 606984
#>   2: municip_nor1101  1027 0 0  0  13872
#>   3: municip_nor1103  8868 0 0  0 131988
#>   4: municip_nor1106  1557 0 0  0  35609
#>   5: municip_nor1108  3058 0 0  0  73684
#>  ---                                    
#> 352: municip_nor5440    56 0 0  0    935
#> 353: municip_nor5441   513 0 0  0   2398
#> 354: municip_nor5442    72 0 0  0    879
#> 355: municip_nor5443   150 0 0  0   2117
#> 356: municip_nor5444  1149 0 0  0   9050

We can then add some infected people:

nor_seiiar_measles_oslo_2017 <- copy(nor_seiiar_measles_noinfected_2017)
nor_seiiar_measles_oslo_2017[location_code == "municip_nor0301", I := 10]
nor_seiiar_measles_oslo_2017[location_code == "municip_nor0301", S := S - I]

print(nor_seiiar_measles_oslo_2017[location_code=="municip_nor0301"])  
#>      location_code     S E  I Ia      R
#> 1: municip_nor0301 59765 0 10  0 606984
